article.title: Clustering of gamma-ray burst types in the Fermi-GBM catalogue: indications of photosphere and synchrotron emissions during the prompt phase

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 1 illustrate about the relationship between the low-energy power-law index (α) measured from time-resolved spectra and time-integrated spectra?
choices: Time-integrated spectra are typically harder than time-resolved spectra.
Time-integrated spectra are typically softer than time-resolved spectra.
There is no clear relationship between the α values of time-resolved and time-integrated spectra.
Time-integrated spectra perfectly match the α values of time-resolved spectra.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 shows the histogram of α values from time-integrated spectra for bursts with α_resolved > 0. What does this figure demonstrate?
choices: Even bursts with a purely thermal origin (α_resolved > 0) can appear to have a spectral slope consistent with synchrotron emission when using time-integrated spectra.
Time-integrated spectra accurately reflect the underlying emission physics.
Time-integrated spectra always have α values greater than 0.
All bursts with α_resolved > 0 have α_integrated > -2/3.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which three parameters primarily drive the clustering of bursts in the PCA analysis shown in Figure 3?
choices: α, β, and fluence.
Epk, fluence, and T90.
α, Epk, and T90.
β, fluence, and Epk.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 11, showing the distribution of α values for the five clusters as violin plots, reveal about the spectral morphology of different clusters?
choices: Clusters 2 and 4 exhibit only positive α values, indicating a purely thermal origin.
All clusters have a similar, narrow distribution of α values.
Clusters 2 and 4 exhibit only negative α values, consistent with non-thermal emission.
All clusters exhibit a wide range of α values, making it difficult to distinguish between thermal and non-thermal emission.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 20 compares the density distributions of α for bursts classified as synchrotron (clusters 2 and 4) and photospheric (clusters 1, 3, and 5). What key difference does this figure highlight?
choices: The synchrotron bursts show a broad distribution of α values, while the photospheric bursts show two distinct peaks.
The synchrotron bursts show two distinct peaks at the expected values for slow and fast cooling, while the photospheric bursts have a broad distribution.
Both synchrotron and photospheric bursts exhibit a similar, narrow distribution of α values.
The photospheric bursts exhibit only positive α values, while the synchrotron bursts show a mixture of positive and negative values.
